author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: ‘Nobody Trusts Anybody Now, and We’re All Very Tired’
description: Revisiting John Carpenter’s “The Thing.”
content: John Carpenter’s “The Thing” was a flop on release. Audiences hated it and critics dismissed it. “‘The Thing’ is basically, then, just a geek show, a gross-out movie in which teenagers can dare one another to watch the screen,” Roger Ebert wrote in his review. It is “too phony looking to be disgusting,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “It qualifies only as instant junk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Queen Elizabeth Doesn’t Take Sick Days Lightly
description: There’s a reason that, in an era when old age and hereditary privilege are largely out of vogue, Queen Elizabeth is still held in high regard.
content: “Her Majesty’s a pretty nice girl / But she doesn’t have a lot to say,” sang the Beatle Paul McCartney in a playful ditty tucked into the 1969 album “Abbey Road.” The lyrics come to mind whenever Queen Elizabeth is back in the news, which has been happening often in recent years, what with the Netflix series “The Crown,” the death of her husband, Prince Philip, and the headline-hugging misadventures of her royal progeny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Singapore will require vaccination or daily tests for workplace access next year.
description: Though only 4 percent of the work force in Singapore is unvaccinated for Covid-19, the government announced on Saturday that a vaccine-or-test mandate would take effect in January for practically every worker in the public and private sectors.
content: Though only 4 percent of the work force in Singapore is unvaccinated for Covid-19, the government announced on Saturday that a vaccine-or-test mandate would take effect in January for practically every worker in the public and private sectors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Biden delays the release of remaining J.F.K. assassination records, citing the pandemic.
description: The National Archives require additional time to work on redactions, a White House statement on Friday said.
content: The pandemic has created backlogs for multiple federal agencies, resulting in pileups of visa applications, unprocessed Social Security benefits and backlogs in F.D.A. inspections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkish Opposition Begins Joining Ranks Against Erdogan
description: With an eye on elections, six parties are working on a plan to end a powerful presidency and return to a parliamentary system.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkish opposition parties are presenting an increasingly united and organized front aimed at replacing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and even forcing early elections in the coming year to challenge his 19-year rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tailyr Irvine
title: In Mourning and Gratitude, the Blackfeet Nation Says Farewell to Its Leader
description: Over four days in Montana, members honored Chief Earl Old Person, who led the tribe and preserved its history for more than 60 years.
content: Throughout his life, Chief Earl Old Person of the Blackfeet Nation could be found in the Browning High School gym, always seated in the northwest corner of the bleachers and always in his blue, long-sleeved, buttoned shirt, cheering for his alma mater. But for his final trip into the gym, he was not in the stands. Instead, his coffin was placed directly on the court as mourners came to say goodbye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: His N.B.A. Dream Was Right There. Then He Couldn’t Move His Legs.
description: A mysterious illness on the eve of the 2019 N.B.A. draft derailed Kris Wilkes’s hopes of going pro. As he heals, he’s not giving up hope.
content: On June 20, 2019, Kris Wilkes awoke in an Airbnb near downtown Indianapolis. He was happy. Next to him was the woman he was falling in love with. Scattered throughout the rest of the rooms of the rented house were friends and family members who had supported him throughout his budding basketball career. It was the morning of the N.B.A. draft, and Wilkes was on the cusp of achieving a childhood dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden the Dealmaker Finds That Compromise Can Have Consequences
description: The president pushed for an expansive agenda knowing that he would most likely have to pare it back, leaving a sense of disappointment that could hurt his party at the polls.
content: WASHINGTON — Joe Biden’s pitch during the 2020 campaign to unseat President Donald J. Trump was simple: Trade in a stubborn, immovable leader for one with a proven record of taking half a loaf when a full one is out of reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: After Fires and Droughts, California Prepares for Heavy Rain
description: A storm is expected to drop up to 10 inches of rain in Northern California. The region is in desperate need of water, but the rain is likely to bring dangerous mudslides and flash floods.
content: Heavy rain on Sunday is expected to cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides in parts of Northern California already besieged this year by droughts and wildfires, the results of extreme weather brought on by human-induced climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The N.F.L.’s Problems Are Bigger Than Gruden
description: Gruden’s scandal revealed the gross underbelly of the N.F.L.
content: Earlier this month, Jon Gruden stepped down as the head coach of the Las Vegas Raiders after the public learned that he sent racist, homophobic and bafflingly misogynistic emails to a league executive and others, including messages that insulted players and the head of the N.F.L. Players Association. It is likely that he will never work in the N.F.L. again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Struggles With Afghan Evacuees Weeded Out, and Now in Limbo
description: No final decisions have been made, but dozens red-flagged for apparent criminal pasts or links to militants have been sent to a base in Kosovo, where their fate is uncertain.
content: WASHINGTON — Two months after the evacuation of 80,000 Afghans fleeing the Taliban takeover, most have cleared subsequent vetting for admission into the United States. Some initially raised possible security issues — like evacuees who shared a name with terrorism suspects — but were absolved on closer scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sports Nuts
description: Katie Hale throws the ball around her Sunday puzzle. Think fast!
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is Katie Hale’s third Times grid and her first solo Sunday, after a Sunday debut this year that was in collaboration with Christina Iverson and concerned little kids — specifically, the way little kids would say “little kids.” Originally from Houston, Katie now lives in London, works as a full-time mom and runs an organization with a friend called the Reading Network that connects children who need books with books that need children. Everybody wins!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: As Broadway Returns, Shows Rethink and Restage Depictions of Race
description: “The Book of Mormon,” “The Lion King” and “Hamilton” are among those making changes as theaters reopen following the lengthy pandemic shutdown.
content: “Hamilton” has restaged “What’d I Miss?,” the second act opener that introduces Thomas Jefferson, so that the dancer playing Sally Hemings, the enslaved woman who bore him multiple children, can pointedly turn her back on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: She Is Breaking Glass Ceilings in Space, but Facing Sexism on Earth
description: Sanitary pads and makeup: A Chinese astronaut’s six-month stay aboard the country’s space station has revealed conflicted cultural values toward gender.
content: Col. Wang Yaping is a pilot in the People’s Liberation Army’s Air Force. She is a space veteran, now making her second trip into orbit. She is set in the coming weeks to be the first Chinese woman to walk in space as China’s space station glides around Earth at 17,100 miles per hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Struggles over vaccine mandates, the death of Colin Powell: the week in Covid news.
description: As tens of millions of Americans remain unvaccinated, state and local governments have introduced mandates requiring public employees be fully inoculated against the coronavirus. And while orders in some localities have translated into a last minute surge in vaccination rates, they are also met with steadfast refusal, leading to legal challenges or concerns over staffing issues.
content: As tens of millions of Americans remain unvaccinated, state and local governments have introduced mandates requiring public employees be fully inoculated against the coronavirus. And while orders in some localities have translated into a last minute surge in vaccination rates, they are also met with steadfast refusal, leading to legal challenges or concerns over staffing issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Chuck Bundrant, Pacific Fisheries’ ‘Henry Ford,’ Dies at 79
description: In 1961 he arrived in Seattle with no job, no skills and $80. Over the next 60 years, he built a seafood empire and transformed the industry.
content: Chuck Bundrant, who went to Alaska as a poor college dropout from Tennessee and proceeded to build America’s largest seafood company, along the way using his political connections and endless competitive energy to bring order to his often anarchic industry, died on Oct. 17 at his home in Edmonds, Wash. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Immerwahr
title: How Is ‘Dune’ So Prescient About Climate Change? Thank This Native American Tribe.
description: Native Americans’ warnings of environmental catastrophe inspired the landscape of “Dune.” Now their tribal lands are flooding.
content: The planet, or what’s left of it, is barely recognizable. Once verdant, it’s now a parched wasteland. The rich shelter in air-conditioned bubbles, leaving everyone else to face the storms and sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Kevin Draper
title: Vanessa Bryant, in Deposition, Describes Learning of Deaths of Kobe and Gianna
description: Bryant was being questioned by a lawyer defending Los Angeles County in her lawsuit about the sharing of photos of human remains from the helicopter crash that killed nine people.
content: The morning started for Vanessa Bryant the way most weekends do for parents with busy children. One of her daughters was at a college prep class. Her husband was taking another daughter to a basketball game. She stayed home with the two youngest girls, a toddler and a newborn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Meier and Karan Deep Singh
title: The Sheikh, the Businessman and a Hacking Mystery on 3 Continents
description: A case that began with a feud in the United Arab Emirates, stretched from the U.S. to India and is now playing out in the British courts offers a rare glimpse into the anatomy of a hack-and-leak operation.
content: For decades, Farhad Azima navigated the shadowlands where business blends with intrigue and the limits of the law. He popped up in the Iran-contra affair, was named in a Clinton-era fund-raising scandal and owned airlines that flew weapons into war zones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor, Glenn Thrush, Simon Romero and Julia Jacobs
title: What We Know About the Fatal Shooting on Alec Baldwin’s New Mexico Movie Set
description: The authorities are investigating the death of the cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the set of “Rust” in Santa Fe County. Here’s what we know.
content: The authorities in Santa Fe County, N.M., are investigating what happened on the set of “Rust” when the actor Alec Baldwin killed the film’s cinematographer and wounded its director by firing a gun that was being used as a prop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Pessimistic Electorate Behind Biden’s Approval Ratings
description: In the era of modern polling, only Donald J. Trump has had a lower approval rating than President Biden’s at this early stage of his term.
content: What’s dragging down President Biden’s approval rating?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba
title: In India, Facebook Grapples With an Amplified Version of Its Problems
description: Internal documents show a struggle with misinformation, hate speech and celebrations of violence in the country, the company’s biggest market.
content: On Feb. 4, 2019, a Facebook researcher created a new user account to see what it was like to experience the social media site as a person living in Kerala, India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Friends Row On After Teammate’s Death, Leaving One Seat Empty
description: Charlie Hamlin, a former Olympic rower who dominated races well into his 70s, died in May. On Sunday, his longtime teammates plan to row the Head of the Charles Regatta with an empty seat in his memory.
content: They called themselves the Four Horsemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Nevada Man Is Charged With Voting Using His Dead Wife’s Ballot
description: Donald Kirk Hartle, a Republican, had claimed that someone voted in the 2020 election by using the mail-in ballot of his wife, who died in 2017. He now faces two counts of voter fraud.
content: Speaking to a Las Vegas news station in November, Donald Kirk Hartle described being “surprised” by the possibility that someone had stolen his dead wife’s mail-in ballot and used it to vote in the 2020 election. “That is pretty sickening to me, to be honest with you,” he told KLAS-TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How I Became a Sick Person
description: A sudden descent into a chronic illness.
content: The long-term form of Covid-19 has something in common with other forms of chronic illness — strange and varied symptoms, lasting debilitation, no certain treatment. But unlike other such conditions, which tend to creep up on society, long-haul Covid arrived suddenly, creating a large pool of sufferers in a short period of time and afflicting frontline medical workers and younger patients in large numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Austen and Khalil Gibran Muhammad
title: Let the Punishment Fit the Crime
description: An unusual debate at a maximum-security prison in Illinois led to a proposal for reform that the state legislature can pass right now.
content: In 2018, at a maximum-security prison an hour outside of Chicago, a debate team gathered on a stage to argue the merits of reinstating parole in Illinois. Under current law — Illinois abolished discretionary parole in 1978 for all future offenders — none of the 14 members of the Stateville Correctional Center debate team would ever get to appear before a parole board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: How ‘Maya and the Three,’ ‘Encanto’ and ‘Vivo’ Animate Latinidad
description: A warrior princess, an enchanted family and a kinkajou musician are changing how Latino stories are told — at least in animation.
content: Take “The Lord of the Rings,” but make it Mesoamerican. Pepper the plot with pop culture references, and you have “Maya and the Three.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Letitia James Isn’t Saying Whether She’s Running for Governor. But She Is Hiring.
description: Ms. James, the New York attorney general, has recently recruited several advisers and fund-raisers ahead of a possible run for the state’s top office.
content: While New York’s political elite awaits some definitive word from Letitia James about whether she intends to run for governor next year, her campaign team is being less guarded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Drake
title: How Literature by Black Authors Shaped One Scholar’s Life
description: In “Read Until You Understand,” Farah Jasmine Griffin explores how books have served as instruction manuals to guide her through difficulty and triumph.
content: READ UNTIL YOU UNDERSTANDThe Profound Wisdom of Black Life and LiteratureBy Farah Jasmine Griffin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: On a Polarizing Team, a Manager Worth Rooting For
description: Brought in to clean up someone else’s mess, Dusty Baker is back in the World Series with a chance to redefine his legacy as well as the legacy of the team he inherited.
content: HOUSTON — Twin traumas have haunted Dusty Baker for nearly two decades. Late Friday night they fused as he tried to clinch a pennant as manager of the Houston Astros. If Baker had chosen to hide until the storm blew over, you’d have understood: He was leading 5-0 in Game 6 of a championship series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: An ‘Unreal Feeling’ as Astros Reach Third World Series in Five Years
description: Stained by scandal, Houston’s core stuck together, outlasting the Boston Red Sox and returning to baseball’s biggest stage in pursuit of another ring.
content: HOUSTON — Depending on your point of view, the Houston Astros are fascinating, maddening or confusing. Maybe, though, they are all of that at once. The world, after all, is many shades of gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Sharif Hassan and Ruhullah Khapalwak
title: Taliban Honor Suicide Bombers’ ‘Sacrifices’ in Bid to Rewrite History
description: The new government brought together the bombers’ families at a publicized event, praising their actions but alienating those who have suffered at their hands.
content: Hussain had just arrived at his office in Afghanistan’s capital when the world seemed to explode around him. It was the morning of May 31, 2017, and a truck bomb had just detonated, boring a crater in the earth, killing more than 150 people, most of them civilians, and releasing a shock wave that shattered glass across the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer, Michael Rothfeld and Jeffery C. Mays
title: What Kind of Mayor Might Eric Adams Be? No One Seems to Know.
description: The vegan, meditating ex-police officer is on the cusp of becoming New York’s new mayor. Which version of him would show up at City Hall?
content: Eric Adams could not resist the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera
title: The Difference Between an Unpaid and a Paid Student-Athlete? Not Much.
description: Since July, the N.C.A.A. has allowed athletes to make money from endorsement deals. Fans don’t seem to mind.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cry of Ineptitude
description: Dry your eyes and help us finish this Sam Ezersky grid. It will make you stronger!
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Sam Ezersky’s 15th Saturday crossword and 45th non-Spelling Bee puzzle for The Times, counting his variety puzzles, which you really should be solving. There are a handful of clues in this grid that would feel right at home in a Puns and Anagrams puzzle, all clever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: A limited C.D.C. study finds no significant change in hospitalization outcomes during the U.S. Delta wave.
description: Other larger, more specific studies, however, have found greater risks when people are infected with the highly infectious variant.
content: Scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday took aim at the question of whether the Delta variant of the coronavirus causes more severe disease, finding no significant differences in the course of hospitalized patients’ illnesses during the Delta wave compared to earlier in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Dodgers’ Ace Isn’t Injured, but He Won’t Start Game 6
description: Max Scherzer, a superstar right-hander, blamed a dead arm for his short start in Game 2 of the N.L.C.S. He said he might be available to pitch if there is a Game 7.
content: ATLANTA — Max Scherzer said he knew he was “in a bind” a couple of days ago when his right arm wasn’t recovering as quickly as it usually does following his Game 2 start in the National League Championship Series in Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What’s the Best Way to Sublet My Apartment?
description: Subletting an apartment in New York requires the landlord’s permission, and comes with a level of risk than may not be worth the rent you collect.
content: Q: I’ve lived in a rent-stabilized one-bedroom in Bedford-Stuyvesant since 2013, and I never want to move out. However, my mother is ill and I need to leave New York for at least three months to care for her, meaning I may need to sublet the apartment. What should I look for in a subtenant? What agreement do I draw up, and how does my landlord factor in? How do I make sure the subtenant takes care of the place, and then moves out when I come back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Erdogan Threatens to Expel 10 Western Ambassadors
description: The move follows a statement from the envoys demanding the release of a prominent philanthropist jailed since 2017.
content: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has threatened to expel the ambassadors from 10 countries including the U.S., declaring them ‘persona non grata’ after they called for the release of a jailed philanthropist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: For India and Pakistan, Cricket Is Never Just a Game
description: It’s one of the greatest rivalries in sports, when war off the field allows it — a contest of national identities that will be renewed this Sunday in a World Cup match.
content: NEW DELHI — The event will be watched by hundreds of millions around the world, on televisions in remote villages, jumbo screens in crowded cities, phones in migrant labor tenements and flickering monitors in the living rooms of a diaspora spread across the world’s time zones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Return to Quarantine
description: The virus scare in my child’s class was inevitable, but I didn’t expect it to come so soon.
content: I started the school year assuming that one of my two children would be quarantined for Covid exposure at some point. I just thought we would make it more than three weeks in a classroom before we returned to remote-learning, shut-in purgatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Black
title: The Amazon of Quinoa Bowls
description: A former hedge fund trader thinks centralized kitchens and sliding scale prices are going to crack the code of making healthy food affordable for everyone.
content: The chicken tinga is the same in both Los Angeles establishments: It’s a bowl of pasture-raised chicken, lentils, quinoa and black beans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Colin Powell and ‘Guernica’
description: He broke many barriers but was outplayed by masters of deceit.
content: WASHINGTON — If we could unlock the puzzle of Colin Powell, maybe we could understand why America cracked up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Life After Leo
description: The departure of Lionel Messi shook Barcelona to its foundations. But on a good day, if you look closely, you can see the shoots of a new era.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — Even by the most charitable estimate, Camp Nou is barely more than a third full by the time the teams stroll on to the field. The Champions League anthem blares, drowning out the thin applause that had greeted the players. Fans pockmark row upon row of sun-bleached seats, stretching into the sky, lost in the vast stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Ralph Lauren Restarts the Fantasy
description: The Polo Bar reopens in Manhattan, and the 82-year-old designer has no plans to slow down.
content: On the deck of his home in Montauk, N.Y., over the sound of crashing waves — a vigorous white noise, more roaring than soothing — Ralph Lauren said he was glad to be back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: ‘Completely Lost’: For Some Afghans, Returning Home Is as Difficult as Fleeing
description: Thousands of Afghans who were in India for medical treatment when the country collapsed are now desperate to return, but have no money and no clear route home.
content: NEW DELHI — The Afghans stranded in India held protests, went from office to office and pleaded with relatives around the world to chip in for plane tickets. There was only one flight available to take them back home, to a country that had fallen to the Taliban since they had left it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Warns of Plan by the Chinese to Collect Genetic Data From Around the World
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 23, 2021.
content: “Once they have access to your genetic data, it’s not something you can change like a pin code.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Stevens
title: Alan Cumming Took Ecstasy to Quell His Nerves on Tony Night, ‘and It Worked’
description: And other revelations from the actor’s second memoir, “Baggage.”
content: BAGGAGE Tales From a Fully Packed Life By Alan Cumming
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Julia Jacobs
title: Alec Baldwin Film Set Had Previous Accidental Gun Discharges, Crew Members Say
description: They expressed concerns over gun mishaps and working conditions just days before the shooting that killed the cinematographer Halyna Hutchins.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — There were at least two accidental gun discharges on the set of an Alec Baldwin movie being filmed in New Mexico days before he fatally shot the cinematographer, according to three former members of the film’s crew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Global Stakes at Glasgow
description: At the upcoming climate summit in Scotland, the goal is to avoid catastrophe.
content: In 1992, more than 150 countries agreed in Rio de Janeiro to stabilize emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases at a level that would “prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system” — United Nations-speak for global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
title: On the Scene: Needle Spiking in the U.K.
description: We're covering the troubling reports of young women who say their drinks have been spiked on nights out.
content: We're covering the troubling reports of young women who say their drinks have been spiked on nights out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Deposition of Vanessa Bryant
description: A deposition of Vanessa Bryant in her lawsuit against Los Angeles County.
content: A deposition of Vanessa Bryant in her lawsuit against Los Angeles County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: What Previous Covid-19 Waves Tell Us About the Virus Now
description: Looking back at the outbreak so far can provide some clues about how the virus may spread in the future.
content: Looking back at the outbreak so far can provide some clues about how the virus may spread in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Truth the Best Medicine for Dying Patients?
description: Readers react to a doctor’s essay about regretting her honesty with a dying man.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 23, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 23, 2021.
content: An article on Wednesday about former combatants seeking veterans’ benefits for fighting to overthrow South Africa’s apartheid regime misstated the racial makeup of the country’s apartheid-era army. Battalions of Black soldiers were recruited to fight for the army. It was not all white.
source.name: The New York Times
